ns0:datafield.ns0:subfield: Personal and business correspondence, drafts of writings, galleys, page proofs, notes, reviews, photos, printed material, and other papers.
American author; b. George Bancroft Abbe; d. 1989.
Manuscripts, typescript, newspaper clippings, publicity materials, and photographs.
Includes typescript of ms. by Abbott's daughter, Elizabeth Abbott Kerr, relating to her mother.
American writer of novels and juvenile and adult fiction; b. Jane Ludlow Drake; d. 1968.
Journalist, author, and college teacher; b. in Canada 1920; became U.S. citizen in 1952; writes on history, current affairs, and international relations.
Manuscripts, printed material, photographs, clippings, audiotapes, and memorabilia.
American actor, comedian, and author; d. 1999.
Correspondence with literary agents, mss. of speeches, short stories, and poems, and printed articles.
English author; daughter of poet Conrad Potter and Jessie (McDonald) Aiken; married 1st: Ronald George Brown (d. 1955); 2nd: Julius Goldstein.
Manuscript for Jewish Resistance in Nazi-Occupied Eastern Europe (1974) and photograph.
Journalist; eyewitness expert on Nazi atrocities in Eastern Europe.
Artwork, professional material, journals, correspondence, personal memorabilia, photographs, sketchbooks, printed material, and financial material.
Painter, illustrator, and cartoonist; b. in Russia; permanent resident of the U.S.; frequent contributor to the New Yorker.

German American author; wrote chiefly under pseudonym Martha Albrand but also used pseudonyms Christine Lambert and Katrin Ireland; real name: Heidi Huberta (Freybe) Loewengard; b. 1911; d. 1981; naturalized U.S. citizen.
The material described in this catalog record is located in the collections of Boston University, Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center.
Collection consists of manuscripts, correspondence, professional material, photographs, printed material, and other items.

Manuscripts in the collection include scripts for plays, films, and television programs in which Alexander has appeared and a number of these bear her annotations. Plays include The Great White Hope and Goodbye Fidel, both by Howard Sackler; Ghosts, by Henrik Ibsen; Playing for Time, by Arthur Miller; The Sisters Rosensweig, by Wendy Wasserstein; Rose and Walsh, by Neil Simon; and others. Screenplays and teleplays include Glory, by Kevin Jarre, Edward Zwick and Marshall Herskovitz, The Great White Hope, by Howard Sackler; All the President's Men, by William Goldman; Kramer vs. Kramer, by Robert Benton; and others.

Correspondence in the collection includes items relating to her acting career as well as several letters regarding her tenure as head of the National Endowment for the Arts (NEA), including letters from Jane Fonda, Sally Kellerman, Bill and Hillary Clinton, Claiborne Pell, Edward Kennedy, Ed Asner, James Earl Jones, Douglas Fairbanks, Jr., Robert Redford, Charlton Heston, Janet Reno, Al Gore, Sandra Day O'Connor, Robert Byrd, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Jesse Helms, and Kay Bailey Hutchison. The bulk of the correspondence (1990-2000), consists of letters regarding NEA matters.

Professional material in this collection primarily consists of files relating to the NEA's work to further awareness of the arts and work with the government to fund artistic endeavors. The NEA's budget was targeted for elimination by Congressional Republicans during this period, using the pretext that NEA funds were supporting obscenity; this controversy is reflected in Alexander's papers. Present are numerous letters, minutes of meetings, itineraries, clippings, endowment statements, congressional records from legislative sessions, transcripts of speeches, court records, and various memos, all dating from the 1990s. Most of these documents are photocopies. The collection contains several dozen photos from Alexander's career and personal life. Printed material in the collection includes film and play posters, reviews, and programs for different productions. Other items in the collection include several award certificates presented to Alexander, artists' renderings of the actress, and several audio recordings of interviews and talks.
American actress, producer, author; was chair of the National Endowment for the Arts (1993-1997).
Boston University, Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center (Boston, Mass.)

Holographs, typescripts with holograph corrections, carbon typescripts, and photocopies of typescripts of his writings in variant drafts; page proofs; some publishing correspondence; research materials; and other papers.
English author of novels and suspense novels; b. Theodore Edward le Bouthillier Allbeury, 1917; writes under his own name and pseudonyms Richard Butler and Patrick Kelly.
A few photocopies of works of others.
Manuscripts, correspondence, research matter, printed materials, and office files, reflecting Alperovitz's career.

Subjects include his activies as legislative director to U.S. Senator Gaylord Nelson (1964-1965); special assistant to U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for International Organization Affairs (1965-1966); fellow, Kings College, Cambridge, England (1964-1968); Harvard University (1965-1968); Institute for Policy Studies (1968-1969); co-director, Cambridge Institute, Cambridge, Mass. (1968-1971); director, Exploratory Project for Economic Alternatives (1973-present); guest professor, University of Notre Dame (1982-1983); and guest scholar, Brookings Institution.
American economist, professor, and author; b. 1936.
Correspondence, notebooks, mss., research material, notes, interviews, printed materials, photographs, memorabilia, and other papers.

Correspondents include Dean Acheson, Allen W. Dulles, Abe Fortas, Felix Frankfurter, Barry Goldwater, Richard Helms, Hubert Humphrey, Lyndon B. Johnson, Edward M. Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy, Edward R. Murrow, and Dean Rusk.

Includes Alter's personal and professional letters (ca. 1977-1983); articles on Grenada for Newsweek (his first story for the magazine), draft of "The Defining Moment: FDR's Hundred Days and the Triumph of Hope" (Simon and Schuster, 2006); various school papers and notebooks from the 1960s and 1970s, including several early journalistic writings, journals, and research; printed versions of Alter's writings, especially his articles and columns for Newsweek magazine (1983-2003); video cassette recordings (vhs) of television appearances by Alter on various programs; interview Alter conducted with W. Averell Harriman (1979); photographs, including images of Bill Clinton and Tony Esposito; and legal and financial material.
Boston University, Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center (Boston, Mass.).

Holographs, typescripts and carbon typescripts of Alverson's writings, some in variant drafts, published and unpublished; some comedy sketches written for Marty Feldman; page proofs, notes, diaries and journals, printed pieces; photographs; financial records; tape recordings; Monty Python film "Life of Brian"; drafts of "Jabberwocky" and "Brazil" scripts written with Terry Gilliam; research notes and mss. for an unpublished book on the Synanon drug rehabilitation center; and 8 tape cassettes made during West Indian travels (1969).
American author, journalist, and screenwriter; b. 1935.
Manuscripts, notes, correspondence, photographs, legal material, financial material, research material, printed material, memorabilia, and scrapbooks.

Correspondents include Julian Blaustein, Anthony Boucher, Bennett Cerf, Jules Dassin, Dorothy Salisbury Davis, Ian Fleming, Theodore Kollek, Michael Korda, Oscar Levant, Laurence Olivier, Terence Rattigan, Leonard Spigelgrass, Ann Todd, Kenneth Tynan, Peter Ustinov, Rebecca West, Jon Manchip White, Robin W. Winks, and Darryl F. Zanuck. Also of note are a group of 30 letters (1940-1941) from Ambler to his first wife, Louise (Crombie) Ambler written while he was serving overseas in the British Army Artillery during World War II, providing a weekly diary of his activities and thoughts.
English novelist and screenwriter; d. 1998; with Charles Rodda wrote under pseudonym Eliot Reed.
American author and novelist; professor of humanities at Boston University; b. Richard A. Andersen.
Manuscripts, correspondence, drafts of writings, galleys, reviews, and other materials.
Correspondents include Clark M. Clifford, Bill Moyers, and Gay Talese.
American author and journalist; on White House staff (1962-1964); worked on the campaign of Jimmy Carter (1976).
Drafts of poetry, printed pieces by Andrews, notes, and publicity material.

Correspondence, manuscripts (novels, screenplays, radio scripts, short stories, teleplays, articles, poems, essays, and articles), photographs, printed material, film reels, audiotapes, scrapbooks, professional material, printed material, financial material, and research papers.

Correspondents from the arts include Bing Crosby, Robert Hemenway, Hedda Hopper, Art Linkletter, Louella Parsons, Mary Pickford, James Thurber, Franchot Tone, Walter Wanger, and Walter Winchell. Correspondents from public affairs include Chester Bowles, Tom Dooley, J.W. Fulbright, Hubert H. Humphrey, Dean Rusk, Pierre Salinger, Arthur Schlesinger, Jr., and Sam Yorty. Notable Indian and Pakistani correspondents include P.K. Banerjee, Ali Yavor Jung, M. Asghar Khan, Krishna P.S. Menon, B.K. Nehru, Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, Nayantara Sahgal, and Brigraj Singh.
American journalist and author, writer and producer for radio and film, consultant to film companies on overseas production, and television commentator; b. Charles Robert Douglas Hardy Andrews.
Manuscripts, printed material, notebook, correspondence, and photographs.
American novelist and illustrator; b. Virginia Cleo Andrews, 1924; d. 1986.
Manuscripts, correspondence, photographs, audiotapes, research material, personal memorabilia, printed material, financial material, and legal material.
American author and illustrator of children's literature; b. 1926.

Manuscripts by Angoff (literary criticism, history, poetry, memoir, essays, stories, articles, stage plays, and novels); manuscripts by others (articles, essays, poetry); printed material (chiefly periodicals); correspondence; photographs; legal material; audiotapes; artwork; memorabilia; diaries and journals; subject files; and miscellany.

Includes numerous items of notable correspondence by many important literary and cultural figures. Of particular interest are letters to Angoff from H.L. Mencken, who hired Angoff to help edit The American Mercury. Also of special interest are several letters to and from Henry Miller, including correspondence with Barthold Fles, Aldous Huxley, and Chazym Geldis; together with reviews and comments by various authors on Miller's Tropic of Cancer, in the form of passages deleted from letters to Miller from Blaise Cendrars, Louis Ferdinand Celine, Dorothy Dudley, Lawrence Durrell, Kay Boyle, Patrick Evans, Barclay Hudson, and Aldous Huxley and advertisements for Tropic of Cancer and other writings by Miller in the form of handouts from Obelisk Press. Other items of note are numerous letters and copies of legal documents regarding the dispute between Meyer Levin and Otto Frank over Levin's dramatization of The Diary of Anne Frank.

In Angoff's general correspondence, literary figures represented include Conrad Aiken, Norman Angell, Joseph Auslander, Carl Bode, Harry E. Barnes, Whit Barnett, Louise Bogan, Herschel Brickell, James M. Cain, John Ciardi, Norman Cousins, Miriam Allen de Ford, Clifton Fadiman, Helen Gardner, Allen Ginsberg, Louis Ginsberg, Philip Goodman, Robert Hillyer, Stewart H. Holbrook, Irving Howe, Zora Neale Hurston, Joel Joseph Keith, Alfred Kreymborg, Joseph Leftwich, Meyer Levin, Bernard Malamud, Peter Matthiessen, Mary McCarthy, George Jean Nathan, Blair Niles, Joyce Carol Oates, Cynthia Ozick, Era Pound, Henry Roth, Harold Ribalow, William Saroyan, May Sarton, Wilbert Snow, Lawrence Spivak, Charles Hanson Towne, Jim Tully, Louis Untermeyer, Peter Sammartino, Blanche Shoemaker Wagstaff, Stanley Walker, H.G. Wells, William Carlos Williams, Tom Wolfe, and Herman Wouk.

Political and cultural figures include George Abbe, Eric Barker, Derek Bok, S. Miles Bouton, Clarence Decker, Bergen Evans, Harry Golden, Emma Goldman, Oliver St. Gogarty, Edith Hamilton, Henry Kissinger, Max Lerner, Eugene McCarthy, Merrill Moore, Benjamin Netanyahu, Eleanor Roosevelt, Dorothy Thompson, Joyce Varney, Kevin White, and Alan Wycherley.
American author, editor, lecturer, and professor; editor of H.L. Mencken's periodical The American Mercury (1925-1935, 1943-1950); b. in Russia; d. 1979.
Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center (Boston, Mass.)
Printed material, personal memorabilia, photographs, scrapbooks, mss., correspondence, videotapes, and audio cassettes.
French born actress; U.S. citizen; b. Suzanne Georgette Charpentier; d. 1996.

Papers including holographs, typescripts and carbon typescripts of Ansell's works (novels, poetry, plays, short stories) in various drafts; holograph notes; galleys; juvenilia; printed pieces; publicity and reviews of his works; photographs; scrapbook; correspondence; and memorabilia.

Includes group of letters and related items regarding the Pi Tau Pi Fraternity, of which he was a member and three mss. by Meir Z. Ribalow. Correspondents include Margaret Cousins, James Duffy, Eddie Fisher, William Hanley, Rust Hills, Lucas Longo, and Stephen Longstreet.
American author, journalist, and television executive; frequent lecturer on topics concerning the portrayal of the Jew in modern American fiction, drama, and broadcasting; b. 1925; d. 1976.
Manuscripts, printed material, correspondence, photographs, artwork, journals, scrapbooks, legal material, financial material, subject files, and film reels.
American actor, screenwriter, and film director; b. Joseph Deutser; also known as J.A. Deutser.

Manuscripts: teleplays, radio scripts, screenplays, novels, stage plays, poetry, song lyrics, and other items; printed material; photographs; artwork; legal materials; audiotapes; diaries and journals; research material; professional material; and notebooks.

Includes several items regarding Spike (Terence Alan) Milligan and several manuscripts by Antrobus and Ray Galton. Correspondents include Richard Cottrell, Bernard Miles, Spike Milligan, and Christopher Monahan.
English author, dramatist, actor, and theatre director.
Plays, screenplays, anthropological writings, autobiography, and correspondence.
Correspondents include Julian Blaustein and Max Eastman.
American author, screenwriter, dramatist, and anthropologist; b. 1908; d. 1980.
Manuscripts, financial material, legal material, correspondence, printed material, photographs, film reels, notes, and personal memorabilia.
American playwright and television and screenwriter; b. 1904; d. 1972.

Manuscripts: humor, satire, poetry, light verse, book reviews, articles, non-fiction, and some unpublished material; corrrespondence, chiefly with publishers and fans; printed material; and photographs.
American author, poet, lecturer, and teacher; d. 1989.

Manuscripts: novels, short stories, plays, screenplays, teleplays, novellas, novellettes, and poetry; correspondence; printed material; notebooks; legal material; photographs; and personal memorabilia.

Teleplays include scripts for Alfred Hitchcock Presents (1960), Climax! (1957), Ford Startime (1960), and Studio 57 (1954). Correspondents include Carl Brandt, Abraham Burack, Gelett Burgess, Liz Nealon, and Ellery Queen.

Chiefly correspondence (1929-1955) and photographs, reflecting Arnold's career and his involvement with public service and charities; ms. of his autobiography; and several scrapbooks.
Includes correspondence from Hollywood personalities and photographs of family and friends.
American character actor; b. Guenther Schneider.

Manuscripts (novels, stage plays, screenplays, teleplays, short stories, articles, poems, radio plays, and student papers), notebooks, photographs, printed material, financial material, correspondence, and memorabilia.
Includes numersous scripts for the daytime serial The Secret Storm as well as material for the television programs Alfred Hitchcock Presents, McCloud, NYPD, and Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea.

Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea (Television program)
The material described in this catalog record is located in the collections of the Boston University, Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center, Boston, Mass.

Collection includes files (1975-2001), containing programs, correspondence (1980-1995), notebooks, diaries, and legal material; daily planners (1981-2002); printed material files (1980--1998), relating to Arroyo's career and activities containing newspaper clippings, pamphlets, concert posters, and concert programs; black and white photographs of Arroyo in various operatic productions; audio recordings of performances by Arroyo consist of reel-to-reel tapes, phonograph records, and cassettes; and memorabilia including various awards and honors given to Arroyo.

American soprano; b. in New York City on 2 Feb. 1936 (or, according to some sources, 1937); officially retired from music in 1989; she taught at Louisiana State University, UCLA, University of Delaware, Wilberforce University, the International Sommerakademie-Mozarteum in Salzburg, and Indiana University; founded the Martina Arroyo Foundation, which is dedicated to the development of emerging young opera singers by immersing them in complete role preparation courses.
Boston University, Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center (Boston, Mass.).
Reporter files (1949-1968); mss. in English and Italian; printed pieces in English and Italian; correspondence; and photographs.
Italian-born American political scientist, editor and publisher of The Reporter, and author.

American author; chiefly wrote novels; b. 1926.
Manuscripts, correspondence, printed material notebooks, diaries, professional material, illustrations, financial material, audiotapes, photographs, and memorabilia.

Includes material regarding the Aspen Community School Teaching Center. Correspondents include Julian Blaustein, Robert Gottlieb, Julian Huxley, Ngaio Marsh, Monica McCall, Herbert Mitgang, Alan Paton, Sir Herbert and Lady Margaret Read, and Darryl Zanuck.
New Zealand author, poet, and teacher; b. 1908; d. 1984.

Correspondents include Jill Balcon, Lennox Berkeley, Lesley Blanch, Lilian Bowes-Lyon, Susan Buchan, Kenneth Clark, Ivy Compton-Burnett, Anne Cubitt, David Garnett, John Gere, Duncan Grant, Victor Gollancz, Sir William Gladstone, V.H.H. Green, Rupert Hart-Davis, Henry Festing Jones, Laurie Lee, Mary Lutyens, Ida Macalpine, Raymond Mortimer, Dorothy Parish, William Plomer, Kenneth Rose, Arnold Rosin, Steven Runciman, Alix Strachey, and Laurens van der Post.
British author and poet; also known as Betty Ellen Askwith; d. 1995.

American author, biographer, and military historian; b. 1923.

The material described in this catalog record is located in the collections of Boston University, Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center.
Collection includes manuscripts, correspondence, printed material, and photographs.

Manuscripts in the collection include Astor's drafts of "My Story" (autobiography, Doubleday, 1959); "The Incredible Charlie Carewe" (novel, Doubleday, 1960); "The Image of Kate" (novel, Doubleday, 1962); "The O'Connors" (novel, Doubleday, 1964); "Goodbye Darling, Be Happy" (novel, Doubleday, 1965); "A Place Called Saturday" (novel, Delacorte, 1969); "A Life on Film" (autobiography, Delacorte, 1971); and "I Remember Elizabeth" (novel, unpublished, ca. 1977). Most of the correspondence in the collection is between Astor and her editors and publishers (ca. 1959 to 1977). Other letters include fan letters to Astor, letters regarding legal problems from individuals mentioned in "My Story", and a letter from Hedda Hopper to Astor regarding a column to be written by Astor for Hopper (not dated; clipping of column attached). Printed material in the collection consists primarily of clippings, reviews, and publicity regarding Astor and her books. Other items include a movie theater program for "Don Juan" (1926), starring Astor and John Barrymore, and three articles about Humphrey Bogart. Photographs in the collection consist of images used in "A Life on Film."
American actress and author; b. Lucile Langhanke.
Boston University, Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center (Boston, Mass.).
Manuscripts of novels, short stories, articles, and essays; printed stories and reviews; publicity materials; and correspondence.
Correspondents include Walt Kelly and Harold Prince.
The material described in this catalog record is located in the collections of Boston University, Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center.
Collection includes manuscripts, printed material, and photographs.

Manuscripts by Aumont in the collection include his plays Ange, the Miraculous (translated by June Hinton, 1959); Beatrice, or the Apple of His Eye (translation); and Madame Ponce (American adaptation by Erich Segal); as well as his autobiography Sun and Shadow (Norton, 1977). Printed material in the collection include Aumont's plays L'Empereur de Chine (ca. 1951); L'Ile Heureuse (ca. 1951); and Farfada (ca. 1959), and also includes reviews, promotional material, programs and posters regarding Aumont, his writings, and his performances (1962-1977). Photographs in the collection (1929-1978), consist of images from Aumont's personal and professional lives, including stills from films and plays; many are identified on the verso of the image. Personal photographs include several of his daughter Tina Aumont, his house "La Malmaison", and Aumont shaking hands with Queen Juliana of the Netherlands.
French actor; b. Jean-Pierre Philippe Salomons on 5 Jan. 1911 in Paris; d. 30 Jan. 2001 in Saint-Tropez, France; was also a playwright and author;
Beatrice, or the apple of his eye.
Boston University, Howard Gotlieb Archival Research Center (Boston, Mass.).
Subject files, photographs, scrapbooks, personal memorabilia, diaries, miscellany, mss., correspondence, audio and videotapes, films, professional material, and artwork.
Subjects include Avruch's long affiliation with WCVB-TV, UNICEF, and his activities as producer and star in the children's television program Bozo the Clown.
Television and radio personality, actor, and philanthropist, of Boston, Mass.; called Boston's "Man About Town."
American author of spy stories and suspense fiction; also FBI agent, lawyer, and government official; b. Frederick Ayer, Jr.
Turkish-born U.S. citizen; author, physician, and professor of medicine; writes mysteries and short stories; uses pseudonyms: Fred Levon and Kenneth Flagg.
American author and journalist; writes novels and short stories; b. 1907.
Manuscripts, printed material, correspondence, and notes.
